title: britain turns against theresa may on brexit sky data poll finds
story: Just 30% of Britons think Theresa May is the best Conservative to lead Brexit negotiations, with 44% saying someone else within the party would be better suited, and 26% answered that they don't know.Britons are uncertain what the likeliest outcome is of Brexit on a day of government chaos.Those believing that there will be a deal of some sort agreed with the EU are effectively neck-and-neck with people who think there will be a Brexit with no deal agreed - 37% expect a deal, 34% expect Brexit to happen without a deal being agreed.Just over one in five - 22% - think the likeliest outcome is that Britain remains in the EU, while 7% say they don't know.Sky Data interviewed a nationally representative sample of 1,502 Sky customers by SMS on 9 July 2018. title: jeremy hunt already doing better
story: NewsJeremy Hunt is already doing a better job than Boris Johnson in one very important wayIf we didn't know better, we'd say the jogging Foreign Secretary is trolling his Tory predecessor&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporter10:45, 10 JUL 2018Updated10:48, 10 JUL 2018NewsJeremy Hunt went out for a jog this morning (Image: London News Pictures Ltd)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHe's only been Foreign Secretary for a few hours. But already Jeremy Hunt is doing a better job than Boris Johnson - in one very obvious way. The former Health Secretary was photographed going for a jog this morning, a favourite pastime of mop-haired millionaire Boris. And the difference is striking. While dishevelled Boris used to proudly parade his baggy red shorts, his successor is suited and booted with proper running lycra.  Will it be a symbol of a change of government style? Only time will tell. He even managed a grin as he spotted the photographers in a shot vaguely reminiscent of a 1980s workout video.  Ambitious Tory loyalist Mr Hunt finally earned his promotion weeks after claiming the crown of longest-serving Health Secretary in history. Two years ago Mr Hunt claimed this is likely to be my last big job in politics. But after securing a &pound20.5billion-a-year cash boost for the NHS, he now moves to an even bigger job - and was shown round the Foreign Office last night. It came after Mr Johnson quit in a blaze of glory and spite over the 'soft' Brexit plan Theresa May drew up at her country retreat, Chequers. title: theresa summons new cabinet first
story: NewsTory Cabinet ramps up No Deal Brexit plan as Theresa May clings on despite Boris Johnson's meltdownThe stubborn Prime Minister vowed to stay and fight despite Boris Johnson and David Davis resigning - and Tories warning she has two weeks to kill off her Brexit plan&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporter12:30, 10 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTory ministers have agreed to ramp up plans for a No Deal Brexit after Theresa May clung to power despite the worst day of her leadership. The stubborn Prime Minister summoned her new-look Cabinet to make the decision today after she lost two top ministers in 24 hours - Boris Johnson and David Davis. The pair stormed out in a blaze of glory and spite over her new soft Brexit plan which Mr Johnson claimed would reduce Britain to a colony raising the white flag. He added the Brexit dream is dying. Last night Mrs May was hanging by a thread as she feared 48 Tory MPs would call no confidence in her - triggering a leadership contest. She is still in office after vowing to stay and fight any contest, rallying her backbenchers with a behind-closed-doors speech in Parliament and swiftly replacing her Brexiteer traitors with Dominic Raab and ambitious loyalist Jeremy Hunt.   But she is not out of the woods yet - with Brexiteer Tories warning she has two weeks to kill off her soft Brexit plans. Tory MP Andrew Bridgen fumed: The longer we have this preposterous and damaging policy, the more we will haemorrhage support. This has got to be killed and it’s got to be killed before recess. Last night dishevelled Boris Johnson finally slunk out of his ex-official residence in Carlton Gardens after hours of hiding from the media - his next move unknown. The Cabinet met this morning in Downing Street. A No10 spokesman said: Cabinet discussed the forthcoming publication of the white paper on the future partnership with the EU and also how no deal preparation work is to be stepped up.  Meanwhile Brexit Secretary Mr Raab and Foreign Secretary Mr Hunt were among the newly-promoted ministers who trooped up Downing Street this morning for the meeting. Others included the new Health Secretary Matt Hancock - who posed with the same NHS pin badge Mr Hunt used to wear. He was joined by Digital and Culture Secretary Jeremy Wright, who hasn't tweeted for years, and Attorney General Geoffrey Cox, Britain's richest MP who famously tried to claim 49p for milk. Mrs May ignited the chain of resignations by agreeing a major shift to soft Brexit at her country retreat Chequers on Friday.  The Prime Minister enraged Brexit-backers by agreeing a common rulebook between Britain and the EU for goods imported to the UK. Addressing MPs yesterday, Theresa May insisted: This is not a betrayal. But Brexit minister Steve Baker also quit along with a string of junior Tory government aides including Chris Green and Conor Burns. Theresa May agreed a major shift to soft Brexit at her country retreat Chequers - prompting her Brexit Secretary David Davis and Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson to quit. The 'third way' plan for UK customs rules proposed keeping the UK closely aligned with the EU in a new free trade area for goods. This will include sharing a common rulebook for all goods including agricultural and food products - and a possible compromise on migration. To appease Brexiteers, Parliament would keep the right to block future changes to the trading rules. But Brexiteers were enraged by this close link with Brussels and David Davis said this olive branch was meaningless in practice. The deal also proposes a common rulebook with the EU on state aid rules, and agrees to step up backup plans for a No Deal Brexit. A full White Paper was due to be published on Thursday 12 July. And Brexiteer ringleader Jacob Rees-Mogg said the plan was not Brexit amid reports he said Boris Johnson would make a brilliant Prime Minister. Yet hopes of ousting the Prime Minister appeared to be fading as senior ministers rallied round her today. Newly-promoted Jeremy Hunt - who once said Health Secretary would be his last big job in politics - said he was four square behind the Prime Minister. Solicitor General Robert Buckland said there had been a realisation that we all hang together or we all hang separately. Grandee William Hague backed Mrs May - with a warning to party ranks.  Lord Hague warned Tory rebels risk derailing Brexit if they follow romantics in resigning over Mrs May's plan - drawn up at a Chequers summit last week. The ex-leader said Tory MPs with pens hovering should know the chances that such resignations will lead to the sort of Brexit they desire are about zero. Lord Hague argued the Chequers deal was the only way of satisfying businesses, the Remain-leaning House of Commons and the problem of the Irish border. He added: A Tory faction becoming determined to oppose an agreement will put at risk not only the government but also Brexit itself. Another ex-leader, Brexiteer Lord Howard, warned against a bid to oust Theresa May, saying: I do think that it would be extremely foolish and extremely ill advised. The reshuffle leaves the four great offices of state - Prime Minister, Chancellor, Foreign Secretary, and Home Secretary - in the hands of ministers who voted Remain.  This will give Mrs May more authority to push through her new, softer plan, which she is refusing to drop. Justice Secretary David Gauke sounded the new note of caution with a warning against a no deal Brexit - just months before EU agreement is needed in October. He told the BBC: There are some who think this is pain free and this is just something that we can ride over very easily. No deal will have a negative impact on our constituents, on the British public. It is not an attractive option at all, which is why we should try to move these negotiations forward.

title: alesha macphails devastated mum speaks
story: NewsAlesha MacPhail's devastated mum speaks for first time to thank people for support after daughter's deathSix-year-old Alesha MacPhail was found 'raped and murdered' in woodland on the Isle of Bute, Scotland, last Monday, and her mum Genie Lochrane has thanked residents for their support&nbspShareByAbbi Garton19:53, 9 JUL 2018Updated04:46, 10 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAlesha MacPhail's devastated mum has spoken out for the first time since her darling daughter was found 'raped and murdered' in woodland. Georgina Lochrane, who also goes by the name Genie, said the six-year-old would be proud to see what locals on the Isle of Bute have done following her death, as she thanked them for their support. The heartbroken mum took to a Facebook group to say thank you and apologise for not being able to attend a vigil islanders organised for Alesha on Sunday night. Hundreds of mourners gathered in Rothesay's Guildford Square, where they held candles and left tributes to the youngster.  It is the first time Genie has spoken out since her daughter was found dead in a woodland area near to her Grandmother's house on Monday July 2. Taking to the Isle of Bute Facebook page, Genie Lochrance wrote: I have finally built up the courage to write this. I would like to thank each and every single one of yous of the Isle of Bute for everything you's have done for mine and Robert's darling daughter. She will be looking down with that big massive glowing smile of hers and be so proud for everything everyone has and will continue to do for her, myself, dad, grandparents and the rest of the people who loved our girl dearly. I thank you all from the bottom of my heart. Last night was beautiful. I am sorry I could not attend. Thank you once again.  Genie added in the comments: Thank you for your kind words. I will stand tall because this is what Alesha would want. She always told me she would be strong like me when she got bigger and what a strong little girl she is. I have the full world behind me helping me be strong and fight. Thank you. Locals and residents were quick to reply to the heartbreaking post. Elaine Newlands wrote: Sending you lots of strength. Thinking of you all. Catherine Gillies added: Thoughts and prayers with you Genie.  Nicole Booth wrote: As a mum myself I can't imagine what you must be going through just now. Every time I saw Alesha she was always a happy smiley little girl. I'm so sorry she has been taken away from you. Helen Dixon commented: Sending you all much love and hugs in abundance. While Fiona Clark wrote: I cannot comprehend your pain. May there be some comfort in knowing the thoughts, wishes and love that there is for you and your little girl.

title: couple reveal nightmare spending four
story: NewsCouple reveal nightmare of spending four months sleeping on the streets after being 'left without council home'Kerry Cotterill and Matthew Gibson slept on benches and in parks after the tenancy ended on their previous home in Stone-on-Trent&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByJack Furness12:39, 10 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA couple revealed their nightmare of sleeping on the streets for four months after they claim the council left them without accommodation. Kerry Cotterill and Matthew Gibson slept on benches and in parks after the tenancy ended on their home. The couple, from Cobridge in Stoke-on-Trent, say the only alternative accommodation the council offered them was in Walsall and Birmingham.  They slept out in the open from March to June of this year, reports Stoke on Trent Live .  But they were supported by Hanley Baptist Church which provided them with food, quilts and clothing and has now helped them land a Hanley home. It has brought the couple's four-month nightmare to an end. They have been in a relationship for four years, have no family living locally, and wanted to stay in the Potteries area.  Kerry, aged 34, said: “I was mortified when we lost our tenancy. I had always had a roof over my head and somewhere to go. I felt ashamed and angry. “We would sleep on a bench at Central Forest Park and we have slept out in the open at Fenpark. It was horrible, I don’t know how anybody can do it. “The first night on the streets was horrible. I broke down. I was screaming and trying to rip my hair out – I was literally breaking. I am thankful that we had each other. “The council offered us hostels and if I was on my own then I could have accepted the place. But I have to be with Matthew because of his mental health issues. They offered us places in Walsall and Birmingham but we wanted to stay here.  “I’m grateful to Hanley Baptist Church because without them we would still be homeless now. If it wasn’t for them we would have nowhere to go.” Matthew suffers with paranoid schizophrenia, unstable personality disorder, ADHD, anxiety and depression. The 30-year-old said: “When we lost our tenancy it felt like everything had come crashing down. I felt worthless and useless. Matthew suffers with paranoid schizophrenia, unstable personality disorder, ADHD, anxiety and depression.  The 30-year-old said: “When we lost our tenancy it felt like everything had come crashing down. I felt worthless and useless. “I promised Kerry that we would get somewhere and when we did I felt over the moon because Kerry is now safe at night and she has a roof over her head. I wouldn’t wish being homeless on anyone. The church has been fantastic and wonderful.” Council bosses say they helped Matthew get the tenancy at his former Cobridge home. In June, he missed an appointment with ARK Housing which was looking to get him accommodation. Councillor Randy Conteh, cabinet member for housing, said: “We understand that this situation is complex and we want to help him to secure accommodation as soon as possible.

title: dad who thought sick b
story: NewsDad reveals "surreal" moment he discovered his dead 15-year-old daughter hanging from treeDavid Clacy found his daughter Holly hanging from a tree just weeks before Christmas after she tragically took her own life - below, he bravely shares the heartbreaking story of her death seven months on&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByJames Gregory09:39, 10 JUL 2018Updated12:09, 10 JUL 2018NewsHolly Clacy, pictured on a family holiday to Tenerife, tragically took her own life on November 20 last year (Image: Essex Live)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA dad has revealed the surreal moment he discovered his limp 15-year-old daughter hanging from a tree at the top of a hill.  David Clacy found his beloved 15-year-old daughter, Holly, dead at the spot in Essex last November after she took her own life. More than seven months on, the gas engineer has bravely spoken out about his heartbreaking discovery that winter's day. Speaking to Essex Live, he described how he screamed for help after coming across the harrowing sight of his daughter's body. He also recalled how he desperately tried to hold the teenager up, but because she was dead she was hanging over, she was limp.  It was just really surreal, he said of the moment he spotted Holly. From that day to now the only way I can describe it is I was looking through some glasses and it is like when you go to the opticians and they take the lenses away. They moved from one thing to surreal. Nothing made any sense at that point. I didn't know what on earth to do. Holly, from South Woodham Ferrers, sent a series of letters to her friends at school before taking her own life on November 20. Her mother, Lindsay, was first concerned that something was wrong when her daughter was late arriving home from school. Lindsay phoned David and a team was assembled to try to find her. The whole of South Woodham was out looking for Holly, but after hours of searching, her parents' worst nightmares came true.  Her dad discovered her dead at the top of the hill. It was too late to save her and it later emerged that she had killed herself. The community have since rallied round Holly's family. Below, David bears all on the moment he found Holly and how he wants to prevent this from happening to others in the future. November 20 started out like any other normal winter's day. David, who lives in South Woodham Ferrers, was sitting at home making Christmas decorations to sit in his window. He was looking forward to spending the festive season with his family. But then, the phone went. Lindsay had text me to say Holly hadn't come home, the dad recalled. I just said 'Well she’s a kid you know she’ll be home later.' Lindsay said 'No this is different, she has written letters. She has given letters to kids at school.' Holly, a pupil at nearby William de Ferrers school, had handed out several letters to her friends during the day. Concerned that something could be seriously wrong, David and Lindsay's eldest daughter sent out a Facebook appeal.  And the search to try to find the schoolgirl began. David, with his son, set out to try to figure out where Holly could be hiding, but initially couldn't find any sight of her. I went down there and could see immediately that Lindsay was upset and something was wrong so I just joined in with the general hunt because it had gone out on Facebook that she was missing, he said. I thought of all the places she could be hiding. I did one search with [my son] and went to the station, and we went all over really but couldn't find anything so I went back, left [my son] with his mum and told them I'm going out again. David and a team of volunteers then focused their search mission on a hill in the area. It was odd really because I turned round and looked up at the tree at the top of the hill, said the dad. I kind of fancy I saw something but it was getting to be dusk and the tree was covered in leaves still so I turned round and went off. After the initial unsuccessful search, David returned to the spot to have an extra look. I went to all the places I thought she could have gone, he explained. I went where one of her friends is buried at the church, I went to the golf course and then I went back to [the hill] and then I said to her mum 'Don't worry, I'll find her and bring her back.'  For some reason I turned left [at the hill] and that was the first time I found myself talking to her when I went up the hill. He recalled how he reached the top of the hill - which he hadn't yet been to but others had apparently searched for Holly. That’s when I found her in the tree, he said. He described how he frantically yelled for help and tried to hold his daughter up.  While I was up there screaming for help I could see people were walking up the hill as there were flashlights coming up and I was trying to hold her up but because she was dead she was hanging over, she was limp, he said.  I had to keep letting her go to go and run to the edge to shout to people to come. He added: Nothing made sense. For once I found myself at a bit of a loss at what to say or what to do. Holly was cut free from the tree and fell into the arms of a colleague of David's, who had ran all the way up the hill when he heard his screams. By then the police had been notified. The bottom of [the hill] was just a blaze of blue lights - everybody in the emergency services in Essex seemed to have turned out, said David.  Paramedics performed CPR in a futile attempt to resuscitate the schoolgirl, but she was pronounced dead at the scene. David, with the help of the doctor, carried Holly all the way down the hill on a stretcher before she was taken to Broomfield Hospital. The teenager's funeral date was set for December 12 - the day that she would have turned 16. Her younger half-sister Lilia had travelled from Surrey to visit the family, unaware of what had happened. The hardest part was telling a nine-year-old her older sister had killed herself, David said. She came in really excited to spend the weekend with us and was talking about her sharing a room with Holly. I sat her down and told her what happened - she just could not comprehend it. Sitting on his sofa in his flat on Clements Green Lane, David recalled how Holly's 'vivacious' and 'happy' personality never led him to believe she would take her own life. If a plane had landed on my head I would have been less surprised. It was a total shock, he said. Keen to keep the memory of Holly alive, David and his family organised a flower ceremony to take place at the spot where she took her life just six days after the incident. David has considered the idea of creating an anti-bullying mobile phone app following his beloved daughter's death. The app would pair a junior phone, the child's, to a senior phone, the parent's, so they would share data, Essex Live reports. This could curb potential cyber-bullying. David told the news site: One of the things that I learned from speaking to the police is the amount of children either being bullied, sent inappropriate material, and sending inappropriate material themselves. The idea is that if you had an eight-year-old child being bullied by someone and they could say to that bully ‘Sure, send me a text, send me any e-mails you like or anything else, but just bear in mind whatever you send me my dad is going to get it as well'. I thought instantly an eight-year-old bully to an eight-year-old is a bully and they would be scared. But an eight-year-old bully would be more scared of a father. A phone is the most dangerous thing that you can give your kid – I’d like to see them give them the keys to their brand new BMW X4 and say 'have a little spin in that' and they wouldn't. But somehow a phone is acceptable. You have got to take away that responsibility from kids – how can you give them that responsibility? You can’t leave them with the phone and can’t take it off them so the only way is to take pressure off the children and get the parents to accept responsibility. The only way you can get parents to accept responsibility is if you get a system in place which allows them to do so. Around 200 people turned up to mark the occassion. David added: The community when they found out they brought these flowers to her school and I was looking at them and thinking eventually these are just going to die and be thrown in a skip. I thought I can’t have that so I looked at them and thought it was going to take me 20 trips to take them up the hill. He said there was a lot of paraphernalia and litter at the scene, so he and other relatives cleared it up. If we were going to have a flower ceremony we wanted to clear the area and tidy it up, he explained.  I put out on Facebook to say we were going to have a flower ceremony and asked if people would like to help. When we got to the top of the hill and looked down there were people still coming through from the gate to help. It was fantastic. It was at that ceremony where the seeds were sown for a new charity set up in Holly's name. David was approached by local businesswoman Sue Colvill, who wanted to organise a raffle.  They managed to raise &pound8,000 at the raffle to raise money for benches which will sit at the top of the hill to create an 'oasis' where people can visit and look out over the town. BAE systems, an aerospace company that own the land, has kindly promised to gift some of its land for the benches. David explained: We wanted to give back to the community in some form. It will be somewhere peaceful to sit. As well as the benches, the Holly Clacy Foundation - run by a handful of volunteers from the South Woodham community - want to help prevent this from happening to other children in the area. David feels the pressures of modern-day life and the 'lack of will' among the political establishment pose a real threat for children. I thought that if only somebody had hired a village hall and asked me whether my daughter was happy but spiky sometimes, whether she is on a diet, if we find she overreacts to certain things at times, said the dad. If they listed all the qualities Holly had and then said your child might be in danger, I would want to listen to find out. This is what we think might be a good plan of attack for us now to think about doing here, to put together an evening with mental health care professionals, invite the people of South Woodham and get them to listen to the story. William de Ferrers School in Essex, which Holly attended, remains shocked and saddened by the death of the teenager. In a statement, a spokesperson for the school said the safety and wellbeing of its pupils is of paramount importance. They added that the tragic loss of the teenager will be felt within the school for the rest of its existence. The spokesperson said: William de Ferrers School continues to be shocked and saddened by the tragic death of one of our pupils, Holly Clacy. The school’s sympathies and thoughts remain with Holly’s family and friends and we will continue to do all we can to support them and our community in as many ways as possible. The safety and wellbeing of our pupils is of paramount importance, and such a tragic loss will be felt within the school for the rest of its existence. Our school recognises how difficult it is for young people to navigate the challenges of the modern world. To that end, the school has robust policies, processes and links to key external partners and works closely with any pupil who we know to be vulnerable, for whatever reason. These policies are reviewed annually and new policies are brought in as we learn from the experiences of our students. We seek to work closely with families, carers and our community to engage with and challenge attitudes, values and behaviours to allow our pupils to flourish and succeed, both in their studies and their emotional health and well-being. David hopes to see his idea come to fruition by passing an act in the House of Lords, and admits he will need a lot of help if the foundation is ever to achieve success. I'm not a stupid person by any stretch of imagination but I am having to learn about things that I knew nothing about, he said. There are people out there that I know we can draw on - there is too much pressure on children and it has got to stop. Sue Colvill, who met David for the first time at the flower ceremony, has been instrumental in kick-starting the foundation, and has even managed to get a up-and-coming singer to be their patron. The Oakland Hotel paid for the singer David Barnes from The Voice to come down from Birmingham, she said. I was talking to him and asked how would he like to be our patron and he was more than happy to do so. Roger Bigwood, of BAE systems, said: I can't help but feel for any family who have gone through such a tragedy.

title: devastated dad left caring three
story: NewsDevastated dad left caring for three kids alone after wife slipped into coma and died following childbirthBecky Parry smiled at baby Hudson before suffering catastrophic cardiac arrest, but heartbreakingly she didn't have the chance to hold him&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByAmy Coles07:40, 10 JUL 2018NewsBrett and Becky together in Dubai, where Hudson was conceived (Image: PA Real Life)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA devastated dad was left caring for his three children alone after his wife slipped into a coma and died just moments after a routine caesarian.  Becky Parry, 32, became unconscious just minutes after delivering a perfect baby boy in the pre-planned procedure, leaving her fighting for her life.  The fit and healthy cancer nurse suffered a cardiac arrest and three days later her life support machine was turned off at Northampton General hospital on June 6. Her heartbroken partner Brett, 32, is now the sole carer and a single dad to the couple's three children - Ashton, nine, Dolcie-Belle, five, and the newborn baby the couple named Hudson.  Five weeks later, Brett is struggling to come to terms with Becky's death.  He told the Daily Mail : Becky was perfectly healthy.  She went to hospital to give birth — and now no one will ever see her again. It doesn't seem real.  I still have her overnight bag from the hospital upstairs, still packed. I don't even want to open her wardrobe.  Each night, at 8.30, I put the kids to bed and I go to bed with them because there's no Becky to talk to, no one beside me on the settee, no one to share the silences with.  The couple had been together since they were teenagers. Becky's death has hit the family hard after she had a normal pregnancy and no problems while carrying Hudson. He was conceived nine months earlier on their honeymoon in Dubai. Brett was by Becky's side, holding her hand, when she gave birth on June 3. She just had time to smile before her condition worsened dramatically. Within moments the hospital's trauma team rushed in to help Becky who was struggling to breath and had a racing pulse. Eventually medics broke the news Becky had been starved of oxygen and would never recover.  Heartbreakingly, she didn't have a chance to hold baby Hudson before falling ill. Brett offered their children the chance to see their mum before her life-support machine was turned off but they refused, preferring to remember her as the happy and healthy mummy she was. Self-employed electrician Brett has described how hard he had found it to accept what happened to Becky who worked as a cancer nurse at the hospital she was treated in.

title: duke duchess cambridge pay touching
story: NewsDuke and Duchess of Cambridge pay touching tribute to Diana during Prince Louis' christeningPrince William acknowledged his late mother during the service in a beautiful way&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByCourtney Pochin19:55, 9 JUL 2018Updated20:46, 9 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPrince Louis' christening saw many touching moments occur outside Chapel Royal at St James's Palace. From the first time the world saw the Cambridge family in its entirety, to the adorable moment Kate was caught beaming down at her baby boy. However there was another incredibly sweet moment that anyone who wasn't inside the chapel will have missed. During the ceremony, Kate and William paid a lovely tribute to Diana. And they did it through music. The official details of the christening, published by Kensington Palace informed the public that the processional organ music was the song 'Rhosymedre'.   This hymn may be familiar to some, as it was also played at Diana's funeral.  Back in 1997 the piece of music was played before the funeral service by Stephen Le Prevost, Assistant Organist at Westminster Abbey.  The music selected for the christening also held a special tie to Kate and William's wedding.  The couple chose to feature the anthem 'This is the day which the Lord hath made' during their son's welcome into the Christian faith.  This song was composed for The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge's wedding on April 29, 2011. The anthem was performed by The Choir of Her Majesty's Chapel Royal. After the short service the guests went back to Clarence House for a private tea, where pieces of Kate and William's wedding cake were served.  The christening marks the first time we've seen Kate in public since the Trooping the Colour parade on June 9.

title: full order service released ahead
story: NewsFull Order of Service released ahead of RAF centenary service at Westminster Abbey this morningMeghan and Harry, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, will attend the service at Westminster Abbey the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge and the Queen&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByAbigail O'Leary10:14, 10 JUL 2018Updated10:16, 10 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Order of Service for a ceremony celebrating 100 years of the Royal Air Force, which will be attended by Meghan and Harry, has been released. The Duke and Duchess of Sussex will attend the service at Westminster Abbey alongside other members of the royal family, including the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge and the Queen. The 20-page Order of Service booklet includes historical notes on the RAF, which officially came into force on April 1, 2018. Pictures included in the extensive Order of Service show the RAF's early days, as squadrons proudly stand alongside spitfires. Others show how the force works in the present day, with lightning speed fighter jets and Chinnooks.   For the full booklet scroll down - and you can download a copy to follow on.  The service is conducted by The Very Reverend Dr John Hall, Dean of Westminster, while hymns sung by the Choir of Westminster Abbey, along with the wider congregation. Readings will be read by Air Commodore Mark Hunt, Wing Commander Nikki Thomas. Lessons will be read by Air Chief Marshal Sir Stephen Hillier and Theresa May. The service will be the second time Meghan and Harry have been seen this week alone, having attended Prince Louis's christening service yesterday. The Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh did not attend the young prince's baptism. Hymns being sung as part of today's service include God Save the Queen, Arglwydd, arwain trwy’r anialwch, Urbs Dei, and The Airmen’s Hymn.  The music  The Airmen's Hymn  O RULER of the earth and sky be with our airmen when they fly and keep them in thy loving care amid the perils of the air. O let our cry come unto thee for those who fly o’er land and sea. Strong Son of Man, save those who fly. O Holy Spirit, God’s own power swift-winged across th’uncharted sky give peace in sudden danger’s hour: each anxious hour and lonely flight, bring calm of heart, and be thou near serene, unchallenged, day and night. to those who watch and those who fear. O’er land and ocean safely bear To thee will rise the grateful prayer all those in peril in the air. of those who serve thee in the air. O Trinity of love and grace, true guide of all who fly through space, in peace or war, mid friend or foe, be with them whereso’er they go. So shall our praise with heaven’s blend and joyful hearts to thee ascend.   Urbs Dei  I VOW to thee, my country, all earthly things above, entire and whole and perfect, the service of my love: the love that asks no question, the love that stands the test, that lays upon the altar the dearest and the best the love that never falters, the love that pays the price, the love that makes undaunted the final sacrifice. And there’s another country, I’ve heard of long ago, most dear to them that love her, most great to them that know we may not count her armies, we may not see her King her fortress is a faithful heart, her pride is suffering and soul by soul and silently her shining bounds increase, and her ways are ways of gentleness and all her paths are peace.  Arglwydd, arwain trwy’r anialwch  GUIDE me, O thou great Redeemer, Open now the crystal fountain pilgrim through this barren land whence the healing stream doth flow I am weak, but thou art mighty let the fiery cloudy pillar hold me with thy powerful hand: lead me all my journey through: Bread of heaven, strong Deliverer, feed me till I want no more. be thou still my strength and shield. When I tread the verge of Jordan, bid my anxious fears subside Death of death, and hell’s Destruction, land me safe on Canaan’s side: songs of praises I will ever give to thee. The readings   First reading by Air Commodore Mark Hunt reads from the Nave Pulpit  The task facing Rothermere and the new Air Council was a formidable one. No other fighting power established an independent air force during the war. There was (again) uncertainty about what the force should be called. Most of those involved talked and wrote about an ‘Air Service’. The legislation for the first time defined it as an ‘Air Force’, a term that had been used rarely. But because the Act had specified ‘His Majesty’s Air Force’ there was no possibility of adding ‘Royal’ without the King’s warrant. The Air Council wondered whether, like the Royal Navy, where the ‘Royal’ had been accepted by usage rather than royal approval, the Air Force could simply add 11 the extra adjective. Legal advice was sought to see whether or how the King might authorize the use of ‘Royal’, or to learn if it could be done informally without the King’s explicit consent. The title clearly mattered given the atmosphere of insecurity surrounding the new service, but the issues assumed an exaggerated importance. On 19th February the Council was informed that the King had happily consented to the title ‘Royal Air Force’, the name it has borne ever since. A royal warrant was prepared for the new service, and on 22nd March the King approved an Order in Council uniting the two air services and authorizing the transfer of personnel from the Navy and Army for a period not exceeding four years. After a complex gestation, the Royal Air Force was to be born ten days later, on 1st April 1918.   Second reading by Wing Commander Nikki Thomas reads from the Great Lectern  OH! I have slipped the surly bonds of Earth And danced the skies on laughter-silvered wings Sunward I’ve climbed, and joined the tumbling mirth Of sun-split clouds, — and done a hundred things You have not dreamed of — wheeled and soared and swung High in the sunlit silence. Hov’ring there, I’ve chased the shouting wind along, and flung My eager craft through footless halls of air… . Up, up the long, delirious burning blue I’ve topped the wind-swept heights with easy grace Where never lark, or ever eagle flew — And, while with silent, lifting mind I’ve trod The high untrespassed sanctity of space, Put out my hand, and touched the face of God. The lessons  First lesson by Air Chief Marshal Sir Stephen Hillier KCB CBE DFC ADC, Chief of the Air Staff, reads from the Great Lectern  TO whom then will you compare me, or who is my equal? says the Holy One. Lift up your eyes on high and see: Who created these? He who brings out their host and numbers them, calling them all by name because he is great in strength, mighty in power, not one is missing. Why do you say, O Jacob, and speak, O Israel, ‘My way is hidden from the Lord, and my right is disregarded by my God’? Have you not known? Have you not heard? The Lord is the everlasting God, the Creator of the ends of the earth. He does not faint or grow weary his understanding is unsearchable. He gives power to the faint, and strengthens the powerless. Even youths will faint and be weary, and the young will fall exhausted but those who wait for the Lord shall renew their strength, they shall mount up with wings like eagles, they shall run and not be weary, they shall walk and not faint.   Second lesson by The Right Honourable Theresa May MP, Prime Minister, reads from the Great Lectern  What more should I say? For time would fail me to tell of Gideon, Barak, Samson, Jephthah, of David and Samuel and the prophets—who through faith conquered kingdoms, administered justice, obtained promises, shut the mouths of lions, quenched raging fire, escaped the edge of the sword, won strength out of weakness, became mighty in war, put foreign armies to flight. Women received their dead by resurrection. Others were tortured, refusing to accept release, in order to obtain a better resurrection. Others suffered mocking and flogging, and even chains and imprisonment. They were stoned to death, they were sawn in two, they were killed by the sword they went about in skins of sheep and goats, destitute, persecuted, tormented—of whom the world was not worthy. They wandered in deserts and mountains, and in caves and holes in the ground. Yet all these, though they were commended for their faith, did not receive what was promised, since God had provided something better so that they would not, without us, be made perfect. Therefore, since we are surrounded by so great a cloud of witnesses, let us also lay aside every weight and the sin that clings so closely, and let us run with perseverance the race that is set before us, looking to Jesus the pioneer and perfecter of our faith, who for the sake of the joy that was set before him endured the cross, disregarding its shame, and has taken his seat at the right hand of the throne of God.

title: girl three new eye socket
story: NewsGirl, three, has new eye socket built from her own stomach fat in pioneering surgery never performed in UKMyah Hauxwell, from Mansfield, Nottingham, was born with small eye syndrome, which had left her blind in one eye&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByCharlotte Nisbet12:40, 10 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA three-year-old girl has had a new eye socket built from her own stomach fat in pioneering surgery never performed in the UK. Myah Hauxwell, from Mansfield, Nottingham, was born with small eye syndrome, which had left her blind in one eye. Despite being fitted with a prosthetic eye when she was one, its weight caused her face to collapse. Myah underwent 10 operations at the Queens Medical Centre in Nottingham before doctors decided to create a new eye socket using her stomach fat. Her proud mum, Lauren, 31, was forced to wait an agonising four hours before she was told the operation was a success. Myah will now need to wait six months before her new eye socket is ready for another prosthetic - but that doesn't stop her from smiling. Lauren, a full-time mum, said: Surgeons used Myah's own stomach fat to build her a new eye socket.  As the socket is now her own fat tissue and is the size it's supposed to be, Myah hopefully won't need a new one created again. Myah had her first prosthetic eye - which is known as a shell - fitted when she was one year old. But although this made her face look symmetrical, it was too heavy for her face and it started to collapse last year. If we didn't have this surgery on June 27 Myah's face would have drooped down on one side for the rest of her life and she would have been in daily pain. Myah was constantly battling infections but surgeons have only used stomach fat that's 1mm thick so the new socket is really lightweight. This type of operation is rare and normally used as a last resort but Myah had no other option. I'm so proud of her, she was awake and smiling just hours after the surgery. Myah was diagnosed with a disorder called microphthalmia - known as small eye syndrome - at just three days old. Lauren added: As soon as I saw her for the first time I knew something was wrong. Her one eye was sunken into her face and didn't appear to be working properly.  My whole world collapsed, I felt heartbroken that she only had one eye, none of my scans during pregnancy showed that anything was wrong. I still loved her unconditionally but I had no idea what the future held. She needed several surgeries during her first few months but she shocked us all when she was given her first prosethetic at one years old which was a year earlier than expected. Myah has never let having one eye hold her back and is always smiling and happy. We've spent a lot of time in hospital and she has battled several infections but we're hoping this surgery will allow her to lead a normal life. The cause of Myah's small eye syndrome is unknown but Lauren couldn't be more proud by how she has coped. She said: Myah was even smiling before she went down to theatre.

title: houses horror inside grimmest properties
story: NewsHouses of horror: Inside some of the grimmest properties council workers and police have faced down the yearsWARNING - GRAPHIC IMAGES The worst homes in Merseyside with buckets of stale urine, hoarding and filthy homes with people living in squalor&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByKate Mcmullin10:00, 10 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThese horrific images show some of the worst homes in Merseyside with hoarders keeping rubbish, buckets of stale urine and befouled bed sheets.  The nightmare homes are being featured now after the sordid conditions that Catherine Purcell, 68, was kept in became public for the first time.  Shocking photos showing how Ms Purcell lived were part of a trial against her husband and daughter.  The court heard how Catherine died in a cesspit of her own faeces and bodily fluid which chemically destroyed her mattress and bed base, reports the Liverpool Echo.  Husband John Purcell, 72, and daughter Catherine Purcell junior, 35, were cleared of her manslaughter on July 5, at Liverpool Crown Court.  However they were found guilty of neglecting the disabled great-gran, who died while being eaten alive. A High Court judge handed him 18 months in prison, and Catherine Purcell jnr 12 months in prison, both suspended for two years. Graphic images showed the conditions of her home in the Merseyside town of Kirkby. But the Purcell's rancid property is just one of a number of house of horrors on Merseyside. Here is a look inside six other Merseyside homes and what officials were met with when their doors were opened.  Children forced to live in squalor  These graphic photos reveal a Wirral house of horrors where two children were forced to live in squalor. The alcoholic parents of the children, aged just three and six, were convicted of neglect in 2015 after police uncovered the faeces-littered hovel. The graphic photos reveal soiled linen, pillows and mattresses, dirty dishes piled high in the grubby kitchen and floors covered in rubbish.  Police were appalled after finding a bucket of stale urine in the kitchen, as well as what appeared to be faeces in an upstairs bedroom. Soiled nappies were left lying around the house and stale food had created a haven for germs to breed. The children were taken away from their parents, who cannot be named, after the intervention of social services. Describing the home as filthy and appalling, Judge Dennis Watson, QC, said: This was not something that occurred over night. This was something that developed and became the norm over a period of some months.  Real life Shameless family  This is the home of Ormskirk's real-life Shameless family who used their bath as a toilet. David Fyles was booted out of his council home in Lea Crescent in 2016 after town hall officers uncovered the house of horrors.  A bath was being used as a makeshift lavatory, because the actual toilet was blocked up with rubbish and mouldy food and piles of rubbish were strewn throughout the three-bedroom home. Doors were smashed off their hinges and neighbours reported how foul smells from the property emanated across the town's Scott Estate.  Rotting corpse found upstairs  A rotting corpse was discovered in a squalid Merseyside home from hell by health officers who joked: Have you got a dead body upstairs? Police and council officials were called to the house in Knowsley after locals raised concerns because the windows were covered in dead flies. They entered the rancid home to be confronted by an overbearing stench and saw an upstairs doorway surrounded by thousands of the insects.  The body of a man, the son of the homeowners, was found upstairs. Police arrested his sister and his parents on suspicion of concealing a body but charges were never brought. His sister, a mum-of-two, was later convicted of neglect as her two young children frequently stayed at her parents’ hovel home and were“exposed to risk of illness”. The woman was handed an 18-month community order.  Judge Stephen Everett said the punishment would have been sterner had police delays not impeded the case. He added: We will never know in the days or weeks following your brother’s death why nobody did anything.    Terrified dogs left in 'unbelievable conditions'   Four dogs, one with a broken leg, were found in a sweltering property in Upton. Woody along with his brother, Duncan, and parents, Patch and Lucy, were found in conditions RSCPA inspector Anthony Joynes described as a house of horrors. The dogs were seized by the RSPCA after concerns were raised over their welfare.    The house had oil heaters turned on full blast, had no carpets, holes in the floor and was cluttered with piles of clothing.   Playground for rats and flies  A Toxteth man hoarded so much junk that his house became a playground for rats and flies. Bill Berry, 55, could not move around his house which was filled to the brim with years of takeaway boxes, newspapers and rubbish. He was eventually unable to get upstairs so ended up sleeping on the sofa. Bill told the ECHO about his ordeal after beating his disorder with help from Liverpool Housing Trust (LHT). He told how his hoarding began after he suffered with depression from being bullied and unhappy at work.   Dogs left to die in agony  Owner Andrew Davies failed to tell anyone her ‘Labradoodle’ cross-breeds, named Koda and Hachi, were in her former property, in Walton, after she moved in with her mum and sister. RSPCA Inspector Helen Smith, called to the house by the landlord on August 8, 2016, was confronted by a grim scene. She found the bodies of the dogs, who were brothers, decomposing in the kitchen of the filthy property – next to empty water bowls.

title: kate middleton broke maternity leave
story: NewsWhy Kate Middleton broke her maternity leave for the RAF 100th anniversary celebrationsKate Middleton gave birth to her third child Prince Louis back in April, but she still decided to attend the RAF 100th anniversary celebrations&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByZoe ForseyAudience Writer12:03, 10 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Duchess of Cambridge joined other members of the royal family to celebrate the Royal Air Force's 100th anniversary. She joined the Queen, Prince William, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex and the rest of the gang for a service at Westminster Abbey to mark the occasion. Technically Kate is on maternity leave after giving birth to her third child Prince Louis back in April. So technically she doesn't have to attend this kind of official event and has been missing from several key things in the last few months. But the mum-of-three decided to break her leave for today's celebrations, and there's a very lovely reason why.  The organisation means a lot to Kate and she was made Honorary Air Commandant back in 2015, taking over the role from Prince Philip. It is understood she felt the celebrations were important to intend if she could, and it seems she felt up to it.  She showed how proud she is to be a part of the organisation by wearing the RAF Dacre Brooch .  Of course it's not the first time we've seen her and she has broken her maternity leave several times since welcoming little Louis into the world.  Last month she attended Trooping of the Colour, the Queen's annual birthday parade. She arrived by carriage for the celebration and joined the rest of the royal family on the Buckingham Palace balcony for the flypast. We've also seen her at Prince Harry and Meghan Markle's wedding and Prince Louis' christening, but these are personal events not official occasions.

story: NewsKate Middleton brooch: Duchess wears stunning Dacre jewel for RAF 100 celebrationsKate Middleton joined other members of the royal family for a service at Westminster Abbey to celebrate the RAF's centenary year&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByZoe ForseyAudience Writer10:57, 10 JUL 2018Updated11:10, 10 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Duchess of Cambridge wore the prestigious diamond Darce brooch to a service to celebrate 100 years of the Royal Air Force. Kate was given the stunning diamond and ruby piece as a gift from the RAF when she became an Honorary Air Commandant back in 2015. She has it proudly pinned to the front of her baby blue Alexander McQueen coat, which she wore with a hat by Sean Barrett. Kate attended today's event despite being on maternity leave, and it is understood she felt the celebrations were important to attend if she could.  Kate was appointed an Honorary Air Commandant in 2015, taking over the role from the Duke of Edinburgh. The brooch used to be given to the best female cadet every year and it was the highest honour they could recieve. However in 2015 the tradition was changed when it was decided women should be recognised in the same way as their male peers - with a sword. The organisation decided to give the brooch to Kate as a gift to celebrate her new role.  Lucinda Conder was the last cadet to be awarded the brooch in 2015.  Speaking at the time, she told the  : 'It is quite an honour (to wear the brooch)  I was the last cadet to wear it, and now she is wearing it. It is the best accessory. Kate wore the brooch back in 2016 when she attended a service to celebrate the 75th anniversary of the RAF Air Cadets.  The duchess joined the rest of the royal family, including Meghan Markle and Prince Harry, for the service at Westminster Abbey.

title: meghan harry visit ireland today
story: NewsMeghan and Harry to visit Ireland today in first foreign trip as married coupleThe new Duke and Duchess of Sussex will spend two days in the Irish capital, arriving later this afternoon where they will meet the Taoiseach Leo Varadkar&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByRussell Myers10:59, 10 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPrince Harry and Meghan Markle will today begin their first foreign trip together as a married couple with a visit to Dublin. The new Duke and Duchess of Sussex will spend two days in the Irish capital, arriving later this afternoon where they will meet the Taoiseach Leo Varadkar. The couple are travelling at the behest of the government, but have told aides they hope to meet as many Irish people and get a real feel for places and organisations “central to Irish Life”. The royal couple were both present at Prince Louis’s christening yesterday at the Chapel Royal at St James’ Palace and are attending a morning service celebrating 100 years of the RAF at Westminster Abbey. Tonight they will attend a summer garden party at the British Ambassador's residence in Ireland, where they will meet people from across Ireland's arts, sports, military and social enterprise sectors.  For Harry, 33, it will be his first visit to southern Ireland - but Meghan, 36, has already visited as an ambassador for the One Young World summit in 2014. In May 2011 The Queen made the first visit to the Irish Republic by a British monarch in 100 years. There she won praise for a speech at the state dinner in Dublin Castle and paid a silent tribute at the national garden of remembrance to those killed fighting the British for Irish independence. In April 2014, President Michael D. Higgins reciprocated the Queen's visit when he became the first Irish president to make a state visit to the UK. During their visit to Dublin, Meghan and Harry will take time to “learn about Ireland's culture and heritage”, including a visit to Trinity College, where they will see the Book of Kells, one of Ireland's greatest cultural treasures.  The Book of Kells is a Gospel book in Latin dating back to 800AD. Their historic trip will include a visit to a Gaelic sports festival at Croke Park, the home of the Gaelic Athletic Association. The Duke and Duchess of Sussex will also have a moment for reflection at the Famine Memorial, before visiting EPIC, the Irish Emigration Museum, which tells the story of the 10 million Irish people who have emigrated across the world. The Famine memorial was built to remember the Great Famine in Ireland during the mid 19th century. A royal source said: “Harry and Meghan have thrown themselves into royal duties straight after their wedding and have made no secret of how they plan to do as much as possible together on the global stage. “They are both really exited about seeing all Ireland has to offer.”

story: NewsMeghan Markle debuts new 'royal' item at Prince Louis' christening - and it might be a nod to QueenMeghan Markle joined Prince Harry and the rest of the royals for Prince Louis' christening&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByZoe ForseyAudience Writer09:31, 10 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMeghan Markle looked lovely when she joined her new in-laws for Prince Louis' christening.  She opted for an olive green Ralph Lauren dress with a matching hat by milliner Stephen Jones and pointed court shoes.  Fashion fans were loving her understated but chic look, saying it was the perfect christening look. But she debuted a new accessory for the occasion - and it's a very royal addition. And there's a chance her new look might be a nod to the Queen.  Along with her handbag and order of service, Meghan was carrying a pair of matching green gloves. We didn't see her wearing them at any point, but there's a chance she might have put them on for the service itself or official photos. Obviously it's been rather hot outside for the last few days, so we assume she wasn't wearing them to keep warm. So she might be copying the Queen, who always wears gloves for public occasions and carries a pair in her bag. title: prince louis christening pictures photos
story: NewsPrince Louis' christening in pictures: All the photos of he royals as the Cambridges celebrated baby's baptismAll the photos from Prince Louis' christening - from the Cambridge family arriving to the guests leaving for the private tea plus Meghan and Harry&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByJo-Anne RowneyAudience Growth Editor11:21, 10 JUL 2018Updated11:36, 10 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Kate and Will's youngest child, Prince Louis, was christened on Monday, July 9 at the Chapel Royal in London.  The royal family were all at his side, bar the Queen and Prince Phillip who couldn't attend due to health reasons, according to Kensington Palace.   Meghan and Prince Harry attended along with Prince Charles, Pippa Middleton and Camilla.   There are no official christening photos yet, but some were taken after the service by Matt Holyoak at Clarence House. They're expected to be released over the next few days - Princess Charlotte's were released the Thursday after her christening.  The christening was the first public appearance the Cambridges has made as a family of five, with Prince William and Kate bringing along brother Prince George and sister Princess Charlotte.  Here are the best photos from Prince Louis' christening as the guests arrived and left.  Our first look at Prince Louis  We got our first look at little Prince Louis who was peacefully sleeping in mum Kate's arms as the family arrived at the Chapel Royal. She joked: I hope he stays like this!  Louis had been kept out of the spotlight since he was born on April 23, 11.01am at St Mary's Hospital, London. Royal babies are usually christened two or three months after they're born.  The Cambridges arrive The Duchess of Cambridge wore a cream Alexander McQueen dress and Jane Taylor hat as she arrived with Prince Louis in her arms. She was all smiles as she entered the chapel after greeting the Archbishop, Justin Welby. Prince Louis wore the traditional gown, a replica of the royal gown dating back 177 years. The original was commissioned by Queen Victoria for her daughter Victoria, and was made of delicate silk and Honiton lace. The replica is made by Angela Kelly, dressmaker to the Queen. After the christening of Prince Edward's daughter Louise in 2004 it was decided that the original gown was too delicate to be worn.  Princess Charlotte and Prince George held on to dad William's hands as they entered the chapel in matching blue outfits.  Prince Louis' Christening guests and godparents  The Duke and Duchess of Sussex leaving the chapel - Meghan Markle wore an olive green Ralph Lauren dress with a matching hate and pumps. Green symbolises unconditional love.  Harry chose a navy blue suit matching the colour scheme for the day. The pair are set to attend the RAF flypast this afternoon before flying to Ireland for their royal visit.   Pippa Middleton wore a pale blue Alessandra Rich dress - she arrived with husband James Matthews, who also wore blue. Pippa is expecting her first child in autumn and her small bump was visible in her dress.   This was also the first time we've seen all five of the Cambridges together as a family. Kate, Will, George, Charlotte and Louis made their first appearance together as a family of five.   While the Queen and Prince Phillip couldn't make the service Prince Charles and Camilla Parker Bowles attended the service - they arrived before the Cambridges. As Camilla left later on she fanned herself suggesting it was a tad too warm in the chapel for her!   James Middleton, Kate's younger brother, arrives in a navy suit.  The Middletons arrived wearing blue co-ordinated outfits to the chapel. Guy Pelly, one of the godparents and long-term best mate to Will and Harry, arrived just before the service too.   The Duchess of Cambridge's cousin Lucy Middleton, Hannah, godparent and schoolfriend of Kate's with her husband Robert Carter and Harry Aubrey-Fletcher (back) were snapped arriving for the christening of Prince Louis. They were chosen as godparents along with Nicholas van Cutsem, a close friend of William and Harry. William is godfather to his daughter Grace.   Godparent Lady Laura Meade also attended with her husband, James, who went to Eton with William. James is also godfather to Charlotte.  It's traditional for the royals to have a lot of godparents, William had six and George has seven.   Kate and Will leave the Chapel with George and Charlotte  George and Charlotte were led out of the chapel as the service ended. Princess Charlotte waved to photographers as she held the order of service. She cheekily told them: you're not coming! as she passed by the press. The little girl wore a blue smock dress.

title: princess charlotte tells photographer youre
story: NewsPrincess Charlotte tells photographer 'you're not coming' outside brother Louis' christeningThe three-year-old was walking hand-in-hand with dad Prince William outside the chapel when she made eye contact with a member of the press - and hilariously did not drop her gaze&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByLucy Clarke-Billings07:52, 10 JUL 2018Updated11:53, 10 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCheeky Princess Charlotte told a photographer you're not coming outside her brother Prince Louis' christening yesterday. The three-year-old was walking hand-in-hand with dad Prince William outside the chapel when she made eye contact with a member of the press - and hilariously did not drop her gaze. Clutching an order of service, the little princess stared curiously at the media before declaring: You're not coming. Charlotte's confident nature has charmed the public many times before. From waving delightedly to royal fans outside uncle Harry's wedding ceremony and skipping gleefully at a polo event with mum Kate, the tot has proved to be excellent value. Before entering the Royal Chapel at St James's Church, in London, yesterday, she shook the Archbishop of Canterbury's hand and appeared quietly happy with herself when her dad said well done.  Why Meghan Markle isn't godmother to Prince Louis - and why she isn't being snubbed   Prince Louis of Cambridge was on his best behaviour for his christening - much to the relief of the Duchess of Cambridge. The 11-week-old prince was sound asleep as he was carried into the chapel by his mother Kate. As the duchess chatted to the Archbishop of Canterbury while holding Louis, she could be heard describing her sleeping son as very relaxed and peaceful. The duchess added, with a smile: I hope he stays like this. Following the 40-minute ceremony, the baby prince looked content and wiggled his fingers as Kate gazed down and beamed at him as she held him in her arms. Prince George and Princess Charlotte joined their parents for Louis's big day at the chapel at St James's Palace in London. It is the first time the Cambridges have been seen together as a family of five.    Baby Louis was dressed in the cream, frilly lace royal christening gown - a replica of the intricate robe made for Queen Victoria's eldest daughter in 1841. Among the guests in the oak-panelled chapel were Louis's aunt and uncle the Duke and Duchess of Sussex. Meghan looked stylish in an olive-green Ralph Lauren outfit and Stephen Jones hat, and held hands with her husband of less than two months as they arrived. The Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh were missing from the small family affair. The decision is understood not to have been taken on health grounds, and to have been mutually agreed by the Queen and the Cambridges some time ago. The Queen, 92, has a busy week ahead, with high-profile celebrations in central London marking the centenary of the RAF on Tuesday, and a visit by US President Donald Trump in Windsor on Friday. The Duke of Edinburgh, 97, has retired from public duties.  The prince's six godparents took part in the service, including Louis' godfather Guy Pelly - who was once dubbed William and Harry's court jester for his wild ways. Louis's other godparents are: Nicholas van Cutsem - one of the van Custem brothers, who are long-time family friends of William and Harry Harry Aubrey-Fletcher, who went to Ludgrove School and Eton with William Lady Laura Meade, who is married to William's close friend James Meade Kate's Marlborough schoolfriend Hannah Carter (nee Gillingham) and the duchess's cousin Lucy Middleton. There for the ceremony were Louis's grandfather the Prince of Wales, step-grandmother the Duchess of Cornwall and maternal grandparents Carole and Michael Middleton. Guests including Kate's brother James Middleton, and Kate's pregnant sister Pippa with her husband James Matthews - the brother of former Made In Chelsea star Spencer Matthews - joined the royals for tea at Clarence House afterwards. William and Kate served slices of fruit cake taken from the top tier of their wedding cake.  Pippa Middleton was showing a hint of her baby bump during the christening service she attended with husband James Matthews.  According to reports the couple are expecting their first child in October and the birth will come just under 18 months after their wedding in May last year.

title: summer heatwave weather driving tips
story: AdvertorialIf you're driving anywhere in the heatwave you need to read this - it could save your car from breaking downHigh temperatures can damage your vehicle&nbspShareByDave Masters12:25, 9 JUL 2018Updated09:23, 10 JUL 2018AdvertorialFollow the advice below to avoid a breakdown in the hot weather&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe chances are that when you think of your car not starting, you think of snowy landscapes and icy roads. But the hot weather can also have a serious impact on your car’s performance – and could leave you stranded if you’re not aware of the risks. Below we've teamed up with Halfords to reveal what you can do to stop any problems arising this summer. These tips should be a big help as you're about to head off on your summer holiday or any long journey, especially given the current heatwave. How hot can my battery get?  When it comes to car batteries (and any other battery, actually), heat is the enemy. Temperatures up to 30 degrees celsius are absolutely fine, but don't forget that it's not just the ambient temperature that matters here. Your car battery is usually kept in the engine bay, under a metal bonnet where heat can build up. Factor in running the car and that the liquids in the battery can get quite hot – especially in this British heatwave. It’s this heat that can cause unexpected problems with your battery and might, eventually, lead to your car breaking down. Dirt and corrosion on your car battery terminals can cause it to operate less efficiently and may also shorten its lifespan. It's worth inspecting your battery when you check your oil levels (or even more often), to ensure that the terminals are clean. Make sure you know how to do this safely, if not pop in to Halfords for a Free Battery Check and an expert will inspect it for you. Too much heat can cause the liquid in the battery to evaporate, which can damage the battery permanently. Inside the battery are some lead plates, in high temperatures these can corrode and cause the battery to operate less efficiently. What can you do to keep your car cool One tip is to avoid parking your car in direct sunlight which can create significant temperatures under the bonnet. When your engine is running, and the car moving, the engine bay gets air blown through it to help cool components. The fan will also help with this, and in hot spells you might notice it runs even when the engine isn't running. If you’re worried about the human occupants, get the Halfords All Weather Windscreen Shield, &pound7.99, to stop the interior of your car heating up too much. When should you change your car’s battery? You can expect a decent car battery to last around three to five years. If the battery is stressed by extremes of temperature then you may see some reduction in that. Check when your battery was installed if possible and consider replacing an old one so it doesn't let you down when you need it most. The key factor in a car battery is the current it can output in normal use. If this is too low then you’ll notice it get harder to start the car. You may also notice some electrics stop working – keep an eye on the electric windows, radio and for dim lights.

title: time waster phones 999 after
story: NewsTime-waster phones 999 after beauty therapist 'hurt her' while plucking eyebrows - but doesn't get response she wantsIn an audio clip released by Greater Manchester Police, the woman addresses a call handler as "darling" and claims she needs to report a "crime"&nbspShare&nbspCommentsBySam Yarwood08:34, 10 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman phoned 999 saying a beauty therapist had 'hurt her' while plucking her eyebrows - but didn't get the response she wanted.  In an audio clip released by Greater Manchester Police , the unnamed woman claims she needs to report a crime.   She complains that she booked a brow tint but says the beautician failed to do an allergy test for the dye, the Manchester Evening News reports.  Unsurprisingly, she was quickly shut down by the call handler who told her it was not a police emergency. This call was one of more 8,000 to the force over the weekend – the highest number in two years. The woman complaining about her eyebrows said: “Hi there darling. I need to report a crime please.” The call handler replied: “Yes, what’s happened?” Beginning to explain her situation, the woman says: “Basically what it is, I’ve gone and had my eyebrows done yesterday. “I’ve rang her and asked her if she’s got any appointments to have my eyebrows tint and plucked. “I’ve gone there basically and she’s hurt me and she’s done my eyebrows without a skin patch test.”  At that point, the call handler interrupts. She tells the woman: “That does not sound like a police emergency, this sounds like a trading standards complaint. “If you’re not happy with the procedure go to trading standards, okay?” The woman replies: “Yeah, no problem. “If you ain’t gonna deal with it I’ll deal with it,” she adds, before hanging up. Police are urging people to think twice before calling following unprecedented demand at the weekend. From 7am on Saturday to 7am on Monday, the force received 5,229 calls to 999, and 3,121 to 101.

title: what time raf 100 flypast
story: NewsWhat time is the RAF 100 flypast? Fighter jets set to pass over London to mark anniversaryUp to three of the multi-million pound warplanes could feature in the huge flypast set to roar above The Mall and Buckingham Palace today&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByGeorgina StubbsDanya BazaraaNews Reporter10:10, 10 JUL 2018Updated13:08, 10 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBritain's cutting-edge stealth fighter jets are poised to fly at a public event for the first time since touching down on UK soil as the RAF celebrates its centenary year. Up to three of the multimillion-pound warplanes could feature in the huge flypast set to roar above the Mall and Buckingham Palace on July 10. The Queen will be joined by family members including the Prince of Wales and the Duchess of Cornwall, the Duke of Cambridge and the Duke and Duchess of Sussex for today's events. Celebrations will begin with a service at Westminster Abbey from 10.30am, with the flypast over Buckingham Palace at 1pm, followed by a reception. Along with Charles, the Queen will present a new Queen's Colour to the RAF in the forecourt of Buckingham Palace before making a brief speech. The royals will then appear on the balcony of Buckingham palace to see the flypast of up to 100 RAF aircraft, a parade of more than 1,000 personnel, and a feu de joie (a rifle salute). Charles, Camilla, William, Harry and Meghan will also meet veterans, personnel, charity representatives and those from the civil service in a reception after the spectacle.  If you want to be in the heart of the action, head to The Mall in London where the RAF will be hosting a very special parade kicking off at 11.25am. The officer commanding 617 squadron, Wing Commander John Butcher, is set to fly an F-35 during the spectacle, and said for him personally it is very important for the jets to feature. That will be the first that we will have flown it in a public environment since we landed back, so it is an exciting opportunity, he said. Now we just need to make sure the jets are in a good place to fly.  Four of the supersonic jets, which had been based at US Marine Corps Air Station Beaufort, South Carolina, crossed the Atlantic last month. They are now permanently based at RAF Marham in Norfolk, with another five of the jets expected to arrive in the UK by the end of July to the beginning of August. Quizzed on how likely it is the jets will take part, Wg Cdr Butcher said he is hopeful that at least one jet will feature in the formation - but serviceability and the weather could affect numbers. It is very early days for us, we are still learning to operate back at our main operating base, so there are many factors at play that could prevent us from doing it, he said.

title: women love peegasm orgasm trick
story: NewsPopular 'peegasm' orgasm trick is loved by women - but it's actually really dangerousIt's also called the "p*ss shivers" and we don't recommend you try it...&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByZahra MulroySocial Audience Editor11:48, 10 JUL 2018Updated12:06, 10 JUL 2018NewsSome women swear by a peegasm (Image: iStockphoto)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt'd be interesting to know exactly how much of the advice spouted on the internet is actually based on sound, medical advice. Take peegasms for example.  Also known as the p**s shivers, this is an example of a harmful trend which should never have seen the light of day.  So what it is a peegasm? My girlfriend recently told me if she's had to hold her pee in for a while, when she actually goes to pee, she often has orgasms that she feels all the way up her spine to her head, he explained on Reddit .
